I only started playing mid-2025 so I'm ignorant of the games history as a whole, but it took me dozens of hours to actually begin enjoying the game. When you first hop in it's just a mess- blueberries (players outside of your squad) all over the place, people saying callouts you don't understand, voting for maps and units you've got no idea about, it can really be alot. But if you have someone whos willing to teach you, or take the time to teach yourself, Squad opens itself up to be one of the more unique FPS experiences out there. 

I've had so amazing matches, and just as many terrible ones- but its the intense and teamwork oriented gameplay loop that always has me coming back for more. You can run as Infantry, roll across the battlefield in tanks or ifvs, fly overhead in a helo, or even sit back at base lobbing rounds on a mortar for your team. When things go well and the team is working together, it feels amazing. It's the opposite naturally when you get balled up by the enemy team, but thats just the nature of the beast. 

Overall I would recommend at about a 8/10, TLDR:

+Provides a pretty decent FPS experience with a good array of vehicles and weapons
+Maps are quite large and give a good amount of variety, even if you've played it plenty of times prior
+Factions within the game have different units, changing how they play depending on which you choose
+Various different playstyles due to the Kits and various vehicles at the player's disposal

-If you're a solo player, don't have a mic, or don't like talking to people online- this is not the game for you
-Community can be a bit overbearing/toxic at times, especially when it comes time to vote at the end of a match
-Matches, even ones that you get annihilated on, can take upwards of 30 minutes. More even matches can take closer to 2 hours. If time is a concern for you this might not be the game for you

Best large scale battle sim out there.

Squad nails that rare middle ground between hardcore mil-sim and actually-fun teamwork. The scale of the fights feels huge without turning into chaos: 50v50 combined-arms battles where infantry, armor, logistics, and commanders all matter. When a squad is communicating and the team is running supplies, building FOBs, and coordinating pushes, it‚Äôs easily some of the most intense and rewarding multiplayer I‚Äôve played.

Gunplay feels weighty and lethal, so positioning and patience win over twitchy run-and-gun. Audio and visuals do a ton of heavy lifting too‚Äîdistant artillery, vehicles rumbling in, bullets cracking overhead‚Äîit sells the ‚Äúyou‚Äôre in it‚Äù vibe. The map variety and factions keep things fresh, and the pacing naturally creates those cinematic moments: desperate defenses, organized flanks, last-second revives, and convoys that actually feel important.

It‚Äôs not perfect. Matches can swing hard depending on communication, and a silent team can make a round feel flat. The learning curve is real, especially around logistics and roles, and performance can vary by update. But if you‚Äôre willing to learn and use your mic, Squad becomes something special.

If you want big, coordinated battles where teamwork isn‚Äôt optional but the whole point, this is the game. Highly recommended.

Reading reviews lately you would almost think that the developers killed a cat or something. People begging for more hand-holding really need to relax imo. Elementary school kids learned Minecraft with literally ZERO hand holding from that game. 
This game is still great and the Unreal 5 update was absolutely a net positive. Many haven't cleared their caches like the developers suggested or refuse to lower their settings to meet the improved graphics. The vehicles handle better than ever, the gun handling is unique and leads to better gunfights if you rely on more than just twitch shooting, and the teamwork that is possible in this game is just on another level when compared to games like Arma or Hell Let Loose. Learning positioning and playing the strengths of your kit are what makes this game SO satisfying.

To any new players: Just hop in, get social, be willing to learn, and get out of your comfort zone to learn a different style of shooter. This isn't Battlefield, but that's exactly what makes it great.

Game is an absolute cinema! One of the best war simulators so far with tons of content. Game requires a high level of teamwork and strategy, while providing all the neccessary tools for effective communication and planning. If you want to feel what a real battle field is then you are in the right place.

P.S: don't pay attention for the recent bad reviews - russians are shitting their pants as the Armed Forces of Ukraine were added (and that update is fuckin cool! Try out brand new Cossack and Vulkan!) :)
It's a good game and the optimisation is fine. The negative reviews are mostly because people in parussia can't afford good PCs.

Squad is the only game where you can go from ‚ÄúI‚Äôm a tactical genius‚Äù to ‚ÄúWhy am I lost in the woods holding a shovel?‚Äù in under three minutes.

It‚Äôs pure chaos in the most beautiful way possible. One minute you‚Äôre building an FOB like you‚Äôre on an episode of Fixer Upper: Combat Edition, and the next minute you‚Äôre sprinting across an open field because your squad lead said, ‚ÄúTrust me.‚Äù

Spoiler: you should not have trusted him.

The sound design? Insane. Every gunshot makes me flinch like someone just threw a firecracker under my chair. The teamwork? Chef‚Äôs kiss. When you actually get a squad that talks, communicates, and doesn‚Äôt drive the logi truck into a lake, it feels like you‚Äôve achieved peak human cooperation.

And let‚Äôs not forget the medics ‚Äî absolute heroes. They‚Äôll crawl 800 meters under fire to revive you, only for you to get domed again nine seconds later. Legends.

If you like tactical gameplay, teamwork, and the thrill of trying to pretend you know what "bounding overwatch" means, Squad is your game. Just be prepared: your squad lead is either a benevolent genius‚Ä¶ or a war criminal in training. There is no in-between.

The developers at Offworld Industries have completely lost focus on their community. Instead of the promised optimization and bug fixes, for years we have seen only one goal - attracting new players. Old, bug-ridden problems are ignored for years!

Unfortunately, OWI has no desire to handle the training of these newcomers either, shifting this problem onto our shoulders. "You train and punish them..." is their stance. There are so many new players that they cannot be taught, and they are left to "stew in their own juice," degrading the gameplay experience for everyone. Administrators cannot cope with the influx of offenders, and OWI is stripping servers of their last effective methods of dealing with them.

Server owners pay money for rentals, spend hundreds of hours on administration and building communities, and in return, they are spoken to with threats, promising to revoke licenses for the slightest disobedience. We are free labor and just a source of income that OWI simply doesn't care about.

As long as sales continue, they don't need the veteran players. So let's hit them where it hurts - the sales.

CALL TO ACTION: If you agree, if you are tired of empty promises and bugs, copy this review and publish it as your own. Let the developers see that we are not a bargaining chip. Spread this like a virus! Let's not let them forget about their promises.

P.S. I will change my rating when I see REAL work on optimization, bug fixes, and a RESPECTFUL attitude towards server

The developers at Offworld Industries have completely lost focus on their community. Instead of the promised optimization and bug fixes, for years we have seen only one goal - attracting new players. Old, bug-ridden problems are ignored for years!

Unfortunately, OWI has no desire to handle the training of these newcomers either, shifting this problem onto our shoulders. "You train and punish them..." is their stance. There are so many new players that they cannot be taught, and they are left to "stew in their own juice," degrading the gameplay experience for everyone. Administrators cannot cope with the influx of offenders, and OWI is stripping servers of their last effective methods of dealing with them.

Server owners pay money for rentals, spend hundreds of hours on administration and building communities, and in return, they are spoken to with threats, promising to revoke licenses for the slightest disobedience. We are free labor and just a source of income that OWI simply doesn't care about.

As long as sales continue, they don't need the veteran players. So let's hit them where it hurts - the sales.

CALL TO ACTION: If you agree, if you are tired of empty promises and bugs, copy this review and publish it as your own. Let the developers see that we are not a bargaining chip. Spread this like a virus! Let's not let them forget about their promises.

P.S. I will change my rating when I see REAL work on optimization, bug fixes, and a RESPECTFUL attitude towards server

When you hit the minimum thresh hold of enough players on both teams knowing what they're doing this game can be a lot of fun. However lately the developers have been been just a wee bit incompetent with the additions they've been adding to the game. Like making an "infantry" update that in the vacuum of infantry v infantry gameplay would be fine but they forgot vehicles exist. Vehicles existing when gunplay (including anti tank weapons) all being collectively slowed leads to your average team of sub 1000 hour non omega tryhards being massacred by vehicles. 

This gets followed up by adding a faction that's utterly reliant on infantry AT weapons to fight off vehicles, which often results in said faction getting steamrolled by the 2-4 people on the opposing team that know they can drive any common rifle immune armored auto cannon equipped vehicles straight into common early areas to force half of the enemy team back to spawn to potentially repeat getting seal clubbed all over again.

Then they do an entire engine overhaul that makes the game run significantly worse, changes how every vehicle handles, and will blind you with muzzle smoke every time you shoot. This so far has resulted in the game hemorrhaging active players. 

The playerbase is still healthy enough that you can probably always find a server to play on at normal hours. That said, with experienced players leaving and the in game tutorial only really covering the absolute bare minimum, Squad has been experiencing a brain drain of players that know how the game functions and help make sure things like spawn points and ammo to shoot at enemies are available for your team.

The developers at Offworld Industries seem to have completely lost sight of their community‚Äôs needs. Instead of delivering the long-promised optimizations and bug fixes, their focus for years has been centered solely on attracting new players. Meanwhile, long-standing issues and persistent bugs remain unaddressed. 

To make matters worse, OWI shows little interest in helping newcomers learn the game, leaving that responsibility entirely to the community. Their attitude essentially boils down to: ‚ÄúYou train and punish them.‚Äù The influx of inexperienced players has become so large that proper training is impossible, resulting in noticebly worse games. And they keep getting worse for every month that passes because the experienced players are 100% fed up. Server administrators are overwhelmed by the number of rule-breakers, yet OWI continues to remove the few effective tools servers had to manage them.

Server owners put their own money into server rentals and dedicate countless hours to administration and community building, only to be met with threats of license revocation for even minor disagreements. Admins and moderators are treated as unpaid labor ‚Äînothing more.

As long as the sales keep flowing, OWI seems content to disregard its veteran community.

Down to its very core, Squad is a great game. It serves as a comfortable middle ground between Battlefield and Arma, the very same way Hell Let Loose does. 
However, due to questionable decisions made by the developers, such as: 
-switching the engine from UE4 to UE5 without any real thought or effort 
-making gunplay wonky and awkward with the ICO update
-and not fixing bugs and issues that have been plaguing this game for years
I can't really recommend buying this game in its current state. And it's really sad, because there aren't really any other games that scratch the modern tactical team-focused shooter itch the same way Squad does.

I am not overexaggerating by saying that if Offworld is going to continue to run things the way they are right now, it's going to kill this game.

The positives 
This games if you have a mic and longer than BF or COD Patience than this game is for you because you will be rewarded with awesome firefights and good teamwork(only if you play in a team and as a Team with Patience).
